current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To establish a national mercury monitoring program, and
		  for other purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Environment and Public Works

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

mercury is a
			 potent neurotoxin of significant ecological and public health concern;

it is estimated
			 that approximately 410,000 children born each year in the United States are
			 exposed to levels of mercury in the womb that are high enough to impair
			 neurological development;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
have found that 6 percent of women in the United
			 States of childbearing age have blood mercury levels in excess of values
			 determined to be safe by the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Centers for
			 Disease Control and Prevention

text.#text: the

exposure to
			 mercury occurs largely by the consumption of contaminated fish, but fish and
			 shellfish are important sources of dietary protein, and a healthy fishing
			 resource is important to the economy of the United States;

existing
			 broad-scale data sets are important but insufficient to track changes in mercury
			 levels in the environment over time, test model predictions, and assess the
			 impact of changing mercury emissions and deposition; and

a comprehensive
			 national mercury monitoring network to accurately quantify regional and
			 national changes in atmospheric deposition, ecosystem contamination, and
			 bioaccumulation of mercury in fish and wildlife in response to changes in
			 mercury emissions would help policy makers, scientists, and the public to
			 better understand the sources, consequences, and trends in United States
			 mercury pollution.
In this Act:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Administrator of the Environmental
			 Protection Agency

means a measure
			 that is used to understand the impact and interpret results of measurements
			 under the program.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail:
means a large area of land and water that contains
			 a geographically distinct assemblage of natural communities, including similar
			 land forms, climate, ecological processes, and vegetation.

text.#text:
The
			 term

term.#tail:
means mercury flux
			 from a watershed to the corresponding water body, or from one water body to
			 another water body (such as a lake to a river), generally expressed as mass per
			 unit of time.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail:
means the rate of
			 transfer of mercury between ecosystem components (such as between water and
			 air), or between portions of ecosystem components, expressed in terms of mass
			 per unit of time or mass per unit of area per time.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail:
means sediment in
			 the uppermost 2 centimeters of a lakebed or riverbed.

Director of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, and the heads of other
			 appropriate Federal agencies, shall establish a national mercury monitoring
			 program.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Administrator
			 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

text.#text: The

The
			 purpose of the program is to track—

long-term trends
			 in atmospheric mercury concentrations and deposition; and

mercury levels in
			 watersheds, surface water, and fish and wildlife in terrestrial, freshwater,
			 coastal, and marine ecosystems in response to changing mercury emissions
			 over time.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, not later than 1 year
			 after the date of enactment of this Act and in coordination with the

shall select multiple monitoring sites
			 representing multiple ecoregions and associated coastal waters of the United
			 States.

text.#text: In carrying out

Locations
			 of monitoring sites shall include National Parks, National Wildlife Refuges,
			 National Estuarine Research Reserve units, and sensitive ecological areas in
			 which substantive changes are expected from reductions in domestic mercury
			 emissions.

Monitoring
			 sites shall be colocated with sites from other long-term environmental
			 monitoring programs, where practicable, including sites associated with the
			 National Ecological Observatory Network, the Long-Term Ecological Research
			 Network, and the National Atmospheric Deposition Program.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall
			 establish and publish standardized measurement protocols for the program under
			 this Act.

text.#text:
Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of
			 this Act, the

To the maximum extent practicable, the program shall
			 be compatible with similar international efforts, including the Global Mercury
			 Observation System and the Global Earth Observation System of Systems.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall establish a centralized database for existing and newly
			 collected environmental mercury data that can be freely accessed on the
			 Internet once data assurance and quality standards established by the

text.#text:
Not later than 1 year after the date of
			 enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, in consultation
			 with the appropriate Federal agencies and the

, shall at a
			 minimum carry out monitoring described in

text.#text: Under the program, the

The program shall monitor long-term changes in mercury
			 levels and important ancillary measures in the air, including—

the measurement
			 and recording of the level of mercury reemitted from aquatic and terrestrial
			 environments into the atmosphere; and

the measurement
			 of sulfur species and ancillary measurements to fully understand the cycling of
			 mercury through the ecosystem.

The program shall monitor long-term changes in mercury
			 and methyl mercury levels and important ancillary measures in the water and
			 soil or sediments, including—

extraction and
			 analysis of soil and sediment cores;

measurement and
			 recording of total mercury and methyl mercury concentrations throughout the
			 water column and sediments.

The program shall monitor long-term changes
			 in mercury and methyl mercury levels and important ancillary measures in
			 marine, freshwater, and terrestrial organisms, including—

measurement and
			 recording of total mercury and methyl mercury concentrations in—
invertebrates;

yearling or
			 lower trophic level fish; and

commercially,
			 recreationally, or conservation relevant fish; and

measurement and
			 recording of total mercury concentrations in—

selected insect-
			 and fish-eating birds; and

measurement and
			 recording of total mercury concentrations in selected insect- and fish-eating
			 mammals.
